introduction.p: Our goal in this activity is to find a power series expansion for f(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2} centered at x=0.

While we could use the methods of Section and differentiate f(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2} several times to look for patterns and find the Taylor series for f(x), we seek an alternate approach because of how complicated the derivatives of f(x) quickly become.

statement.p: What is the Taylor series expansion for g(x) = \frac{1}{1-x}? What is the interval of convergence of this series?

hint.p: Small hints for each of the prompts above.

solution.p:
Recall that
g(x) = \frac{1}{1-x} = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} x^k
for -1 \lt x \lt 1.

statement.p: How is g(-x^2) related to f(x)? Explain, and hence substitute -x^2 for x in the power series expansion for g(x). Given the relationship between g(-x^2) and f(x), how is the resulting series related to f(x)?

solution.p: Substituting -x^2 for x in the power series expansion for g(x) gives f(x) \amp = g(-x^2)\amp = \frac{1}{1-(-x^2)}\amp = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \left(-x^2\right)^k\amp = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} (-1)^k x^{2k}.

statement.p: For which values of x will this power series expansion for f(x) be valid? Why?

solution.p: This power series expansion for f(x) will be valid as long as -1 \lt (-x)^2 \lt 1 or for -1 \lt x \lt 1.
